Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

BJP Candidate List.description: NEW DELHI: Amid rumblings over ticket denials in some seats like Kanpur, where saffron veteran   Murli Manohar Joshi has been benched   , and Bangalore South, where the wife of late party leader Ananth Kumar was overlooked for a young debutant, BJP issued on Tuesday a list of 43 nominees for the Lok Sabha polls. Not budging in the face of Joshi’s stiff resistance to being asked to step aside, BJP announced Satyadev Pachauri, a minister in the UP cabinet, as the replacement for the octogenarian leader. The list of 30 candidates for UP, however, accommodated women and child welfare minister Maneka Gandhi and her son Varun Gandhi, who were allowed to swap their Pilibhit and Sultanpur seats. Other interesting picks include   actor-politician Jaya Prada   , who was named against SP leader Azam Khan from Rampur in UP soon after she joined BJP. The selection ignites an old and bitter rivalry, as the former Bollywood star is close to former SP leader Amar Singh who has scores to settle with SP and Khan. Another UP cabinet minister, Rita Bahuguna Joshi, a former UP Congress chief who joined BJP, will contest from the prestigious constituency of Allahabad, where the sitting party MP, Shyama Charab Gupta, has left for SP and is contesting from Banda. She is the daughter of the late H N Bahuguna, a former UP chief minister and well-known Congress leader. Law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad, the party’s candidate from Patna Sahib, faced protests when he landed in Patna on Tuesday. The protesters claimed loyalty to BJP’s Rajya Sabha MP R K Sinha, who was later pulled up by the party while sources said the heckling was led by a person identified as an expelled BJP member. Varun Gandhi, who has had his ups and downs in BJP, was on the list of nominees and will stake his claim for Pilibhit, which has been a family bastion. Maneka Gandhi will be pitted in a triangular contest against SP-BSP alliance candidate Chandrabhanu Singh, alias Sonu Singh, a local politician with clout among Rajput voters who could have turned up the heat for Varun. Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh is in the fray as the Congress nominee. Joshi, a former BJP president, made no secret of his displeasure at being denied a ticket and went public by releasing a letter addressed to voters of Kanpur saying he received a call from party general secretary (organisation) Ramlal asking him not to contest the polls. Joshi, 85, has been asked not to contest just as it was decided that 91-year-old party patriarch L K Advani will not fight from Gandhinagar. Joshi’s defiant note was possibly the reason behind the nomination of a Brahmin face as another UP state minister, Satish Mahana, had been talked of as the frontrunner to replace the veteran leader The party decision is in line with several veterans not being nominated to pave way for younger leaders. The 2019 election will see the curtain drop on the electoral politics of what was seen the Vajpayee-Advani era in the party. BJP has also not given tickets to B C Khanduri, Karia Munda, Kalraj Mishra, Bijoya Chakravarty — all MPs for several terms and over 80 years of age. BJP sprang a surprise by giving 28-year-old Tejaswi Surya, an advocate and Karnataka Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha general secretary, the ticket from Bangalore South, belying expectations that Tejaswini Ananth Kumar would be its choice for the constituency her husband represented six times. The choice triggered strong protests and even state BJP president B S Yeddyurappa said they had sent only Tejaswini’s name, which, he claimed, was changed in Delhi. Tejaswini had to issue statements to mollify her supporters as she said the polls were about re-electing Narendra Modi as Prime Minister. BJP has announced 349 candidates, including 62 in UP, so far. Two seats in UP have been left for alliance partner Apna Dal (Sonelal). Party president Amit Shah will decide the remaining 16 seats in UP where sitting MPs are likely to be replaced, and a reason behind delaying the announcement is to reduce prospects of dissidence and rebellion. The party has so far dropped 14 sitting MPs in UP. BJP general secretary Arun Singh announced that Union minister Manoj Sinha has been fielded from Ghazipur, a seat he had won in 2014. BJP’s Kisan Morcha chief Birendra Singh Mast has been shifted from his sitting seat Bhadohi to far-east Ballia in UP, replacing sitting MP Bharat Singh, whose poor performance was a concern for the party. Agra MP Ram Shankar Katheria, head of the SC commission who had been denied renomination from the current seat, has been moved to Etawah (SC), replacing Ashok Kumar Dohray. UP BJP president Mahendra Nath Pandey has been repeated from Chandauli. In Video:No Murli Manohar Joshi in BJP list of 43Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

With no solution, mining cos feel pressu.description: PANAJI: While smaller mining firms and ancillary units have already laid off staff, the pressure is now building on larger mining companies to retrench direct employees, who number between 25,000 to 30,000 in Goa, said Goa Mineral Ore Exporters’ Association (GMOEA). With the state government struggling to find a way to restart mining operations, the association said that some mining firms had already begun to offer employees voluntary retirement schemes (VRS) and other financial options. The Supreme Court in February 2018 quashed the second renewal of iron ore mining leases given to 88 companies, bringing mining operations in the state to a halt from March 16, 2018. “From May 2012 to October 2015 was the first time that mining was halted, but even then majority of the companies gave no layoffs or it was very minimal. Since last year the pressure is building on a day-to-day basis, so much so that companies are offering financial options to their employees to take VRS or take settlement,” managing director of Fomento Resources and GMOEA president Ambar Timblo said. Chief minister Pramod Sawant met with a delegation of mining dependant people, who informed him about the pressure to retrench workers. Sawant in a statement urged mining firms not to retrench staff since mining activities could resume in November. Timblo said that larger companies, who have diversified interests such as Vedanta and Fomento Resources, have the capacity to bear the financial burden of salaries and overheads for a longer duration. However, in eight months to a year even these companies will struggle to keep staff on their payrolls. “The larger business houses and mining companies like a Vedanta or a Salgaocar or Chowgule are the last ones to do the layoffs. The first layoffs were the labour that came from outside of Goa. Then it will be the lower income employees,” he said. Retrenching confirmed employees, who have been working for decades with companies, will be most difficult, he added. In July 2018, Chowgule and Company Pvt Ltd, has sought permission from the ministry of labour and employment to lay off 347 permanent employees in the state. In April, another company informed workers that they would be retrenched and would be compensated with a month’s wage. “Everybody else who subcontracted, had machinery contractors or truck business have laid off much earlier in 2013, 2014 and 2015. They have been consistently retrenching because there has been absolutely no business other than one-and-half-year for the industry,” Timblo said. The GMOEA, which remains optimistic, met with NITI Aayog officials where they gave a presentation on Goa’s mining industry and the possible steps to restart operations in the state. Priyanka Gandhi.description: RAE BARELI: In her scathing attack on BJP and Modi government, Congress general secretary Priyanka Gandhi said that Congress doesn't need any certificate from anyone to prove its nationalist feelings. "Ye brashtachar ki baat karnewale sabse bade brashta hain… kaam ki baat karte hain magar sabse bade nikamme hain… dharma ki baat karne wale sabse bada adharm kar rahe hain - dharm ka istemal kar rahe hain… saheedon ka istemal kar rahe hain - sirf rajinit ke liye (They are talking of acting against corruption but are corrupt themselves… they talk of work but are good for nothing… they talk of dharma (read duties) but indulge in adharma by defying its norms - they use religion and martyrs for political interests)," Priyanka stated in her closed door meeting with cadres on Thursday. The Congress leader hit out at BJP's strategy of playing the nationalist card. "We are Congress… we launched the freedom movement… gave our blood and sweat… braved British atrocities … we don't need any certificate to prove our nationalist feelings especially from the ones who apologised to the British at that time", asserted Priyanka, urging the workers to go to every household in their area and meet every voter. She directed the workers to apprise the voters that the 2019 Lok Sabha election was as important as the freedom movement. Infusing energy in them she said, "Don't be afraid of anything as this is a weak government. Only a weak government curbs the voice of the people, which is a crime in democracy." Priyanka asked the workers to stand up for their leader whose only dream is the progress of India and its people. "Rahul thinks of the people without any vested interest," Priyanka said citing the example of her conversation with Rahul on the issue of using self-help group women for campaigning. "When I proposed to him this idea, he simply denied… saying that I created the SHGs to empower women, not use them in any way," Priyanka said quoting her brother. The Congress general secretary told the workers that she was working on mission 2022. "We will, with your support, form the government in 2022. And once we come, we will stay here for long on the basis of our hard work," she said adding that the hard-workers would be adequately rewarded. In one of worst-ever delays, IMD says mo.description: PANAJI: The onset of the monsoon is likely to be delayed by a fortnight as, India Meteoroligical Department (IMD), Panaji has set a fresh date for its likely arrival on June 22. While this may be the most delayed monsoon in a decade, the IMD had earlier forecast that monsoon would hit Goa between June 12-15. Though the monsoon arrived in Kerala, there is no further progress as of now. “Our analysis shows it will take four to five days for the monsoon to hit Goa. It may vary. Regarding the monsoon onset statistics, we have to check our records for further clarification on whether it is the most delayed monsoon in the last two decades or not. We expect the monsoon to progress upwards in a few days towards the north of the peninsula,” IMD director, K V Padgalwar said. The department has attributed the delay in the monsoon in Goa to cyclone Vayu absorbing moisture from the west coast before taking it along towards the north of the peninsula. The delay has also increased the rain deficit further. As of now, Padgalwar said, the conditions for the monsoon are not favourable. “Any trough visible in the western coast is known as an off-shore trough. Currently, there is no off-shore trough here. The depression in the Bay of Bengal is not moving either. It is stagnated there for the past four to five days, its position is the same,” he said. Parts of the state experienced cloudy weather on Tuesday. The department this to south westerly winds bringing in moisture, thus developing clouds. But this moisture is not enough to result in rain. The weather alert cautioning fishermen from venturing into the seas is still active as a result. “The information provided from buoys has reported winds blowing at 20-30 knots. It’s not advisable for fishermen to venture into the sea.” Padgalwar said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Amid Fomento-MMC trash talk, town suffer.description: MARGAO: In the slugfest between MMC and Fomento over the municipal solid waste plant at Sonsoddo, Margao is made to suffer in silence. MMC and Fomento may each argue that the other is to blame for the crisis, but as per the concession agreement signed between the two, a copy of which is with TOI, both are equally at fault. If Fomento failed to put into operation the landfill at the site for safe disposal of inert, MMC never bothered to cart away the reject of the unprocessed waste as mandated in the agreement. Resultantly, the inert and the reject, both comprising nearly 60% of the incoming daily waste, landed atop the decades-old mountain of garbage. A source closely associated with the setting up of the plant told TOI that the concession agreement never mandated that MMC segregate the waste and instead entailed the task to be carried out by Fomento. Fomento argues that the non-segregation of waste was the failure behind the plant not working at an optimum level. And therein lies the rub. “As MMC failed to provide us with segregated waste, the reject (of unprocessed waste) were on the higher side. Despite many reminders from time to time, MMC failed to cart away the reject, and therefore, left with no option, this 35-40% of the waste, along with the inert (15-20% of the waste), would be piled atop the existing garbage dump,” a company official said. Resultantly, the decades-old mountain of garbage, which was what was originally intended to be eliminated as per the agreement, kept on rising raising questions about the efficacy of the plant. “The MSW Rules 2016 that mandate segregation at source came into force only in 2016, while the concession agreement was signed in 2011. It’s clear Fomento intends to fall back on the changes in rules to defend its failure,” a source closely associated with the setting up of the plant told TOI. Moreover, MMC also failed to put in any monitoring mechanism to oversee the operations of the plant, as outlined in the concession agreement. “The MMC never bothered to reply to the correspondence made to it by Fomento, and mutely acted as per the dictates of Fomento. It’s now paying the price for being a silent spectator, or rather turning its eye away from the irregularities at Sonsoddo,” former chairperson of MMC Savio Coutinho, during whose tenure the concession agreement was inked, said. The foundation stone for the plant was laid on October 2, 2011. As per the original concession agreement, Fomento and IL&FS were to set up a 50-75 tonne per day capacity plant on design, build, own, operate and transfer (DBOOT) basis for a period of 25 years, at a cost of Rs 7.3 crore. However, sources said the plant never became fully functional as Fomento failed to make the landfill at the site operational. Inert, non-biodegradable residual matter of processed waste comprising 15-20% of the waste processed, had to be dumped here. The underbelly of the operations at Sonsoddo was exposed only after the recent fire at the dump. With locals protesting against more dumping of waste here, Fomento began piling the reject inside the plant until there was not enough space to handle incoming garbage. That was when Fomento blocked entry to MMC’s garbage trucks since Monday, triggering the crisis. Spread over 15,000sqm and containing 1.5 lakh tonne of mixed waste — and still rising with every passing day — the dump has turned out to be a major challenge for the MMC and the government, as acknowledged by deputy chief minister Vijai Sardesai. The original proposal was to set up the plant after clearing one half of the garbage dump, while the remainder was to be capped with impermeable layers after screening the waste. “Gas wells would be constructed to take out methane and other gases formed inside. Peripheral roads will be built for material movement and inspection. The capped dump would have post-closure protocol to take care of the facility for 15 years and to monitor the leachate and gas production and to see that there is no harm to the environment,” the plant’s project proposal stated. However, this technical requirement was rendered redundant after MMC provided additional 57,700sqm land adjoining the existing garbage dump, for setting up the plant. Subsequently, Fomento came out with a proposal for scientific capping of the garbage dump, an idea that was, however, shot down by the Goa State Pollution Control Board citing environmental concerns. The change in location of the plant and the proposal for scientific capping of the garbage dump meant doing away with the necessity of segregating and treating the garbage dump. Though scientific capping of the garbage dump failed to materialise, the original idea of eliminating the old dump was conveniently relegated to the back-burner. A source well versed with the legal matters of MMC, requesting anonymity, expressed apprehensions that the recent developments at Sonsoddo could help Fomento leverage the situation to its advantage by forcing MMC to terminate the agreement, and consequently enter into litigation and claim substantial costs. “Nevertheless, it’s imperative that the government intervene in the matter and salvage the situation in the interests of the city and its people. Waste management technology keeps on innovating every four-five years and thus, the technology employed at Sonsoddo plant appears to have been outdated. An innovative technological solution is what is needed at Sonsoddo,” the source said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Goa govt orders NGPDA to start Panaji, M.description: PANAJI: The state government has directed the North Goa Planning and Development Authority (NGPDA) to revise the Mapusa and Panaji outline development plans (ODP) by preparing a land use map and register for the two cities. The decision to start the process afresh was subsequently taken by NGPDA at its 73rd meeting on Monday. A resolution was also taken to complete the entire process within nine months. “This ODP was prepared in 2016 and has been asked to be redone,” said NGPDA chairman Michael Lobo. “NGPDA met today and it has been decided that the Mapusa land use map and register will be prepared along with that of Panaji.” Lobo said that when ODP was prepared in 2016, NGPDA chose not to prepare a land use map and register, which was the main reason for starting the ODP process from scratch. “The land use map and register for Panaji were not there since there was an existing ODP. We took the ODP as a base map. But the government has asked us to make a fresh land use map and register to identify all structures, including small structures and also government structures and pumping stations,” Lobo said. Every structure, whether residential, commercial, government and even utilities will be mapped this time to ensure that land utilization is clearly depicted in the ODP. The planning body will also identify encroachments on government and private land. Lobo, however, did not specify what action will be taken against such encroachments. “There is a lot of land touching the river where there are encroachments. There is land which has been used for various government projects which otherwise on the plan is shown as orchard or vacant land. We need to specify what it has been used for,” Lobo said. NGPDA will begin the process by issuing a public notice inviting objections and suggestions from the public. The entire process to map the structures in Mapusa and Panaji will be contracted to a private agency which will then prepare the land use map. This time around, Lobo said, NGPDA has also decided to get on board councillors from the local municipal bodies. Lobo has urged the Corporation of the City of Panaji and the Mapusa Municipal Council to help NGPDA with the drafting process. “We will come up with a tender notice to see that we take an agency on board to mark all these structures and give us a ready map. Local councillors and the people have to give suggestions and objections which have to tally with the agency’s work,” said Lobo. The MLA said the process to prepare the land use map and register will take three months and preparation of the draft ODP will take two months, while the final ODP will take another three months. Margao ground becomes mini Sonsoddo afte.description: MARGAO: A sea of plastic waste, mixed with wet waste and other garbage, left behind by stalls from the Margao Purumentache fair turned the SGPDA ground into a mini Sonsoddo on Wednesday. The eye sore, which is in blatant violation of the plastic ban, comes at a time when the city is already grappling with garbage problems and despite the municipality stating that the fair would be plastic-free this year. Water was seen stagnating in the plastic waste as vendors packed up and left. President of the New Market Traders Association Vinod Shirodkar said this will result in breeding of mosquitoes and a rise in dengue and other vector-borne diseases. The plastic ban, he said, is only being forced on traders at the new market. “Don’t the rules apply to them too? Who is taking action against them? First take action on those who left behind the garbage and then impose the plastic ban on others,” Shirodkar said. Instead of imposing fines on shops handing out plastic bags, stop the problem at the source, he said. “First shut the factories producing plastic bags. You’re keeping the factories open and huge trucks bearing plastic bags are being brought in. Why aren’t they being stopped on the way and action taken against them?” Shirodkar said. Margao resident Jose Marie Miranda said the “complete mess” left behind after the fair is the same story every year. “There is absolutely no control on the garbage generated at the fair. There should have been bins in place to collect garbage and those responsible should have been penalised,” Miranda said. Former chairperson of the municipal council Savio Coutinho said this has only added to the municipality’s garbage problem. “The contractor has left behind the waste, but the municipality that doesn’t have enough manpower and is already under pressure to deal with garbage is being overburdened with this additional garbage,” Coutinho said. Goa: Women can now change name in marria.description: PANAJI: Non-Hindu brides will now be able to officially change their names at the time of registering their marriage. The law and judiciary department has issued a notification extending the facility to all women, irrespective of religion or community. In TOI's June 14 report, former law minister Nilesh Cabral had announced that every bride would soon be given the option of changing her name at the time of registering her marriage. The notification will come as a relief not only to new brides but also to those who have registered their marriages in the past. "There is no cut-off date. Any woman wishing to change her name by adopting her husband's surname can apply for a correction in her marriage certificate. It will be corrected and given to her," an official said, adding that those interested will have to make an application and produce proof of their husbands' identity. Since pre-Liberation days, the option of adopting the husband's surname in the marriage certificate at the time of registration was available only to Hindu brides. Women from Christian, Muslim and other communities were forced to go through the cumbersome process of changing their names later, by producing various documents and even publishing a notice in the government gazette. The new notification will also address a flaw in the system where the name of the mother would erroneously appear with her husband's surname whether she had adopted it or not in a child's birth certificate. "In pursuance of Article 43 of the Civil Marriage Decree, 1910, the government of Goa hereby notifies that the bride, irrespective of the religion/community, may change her name/middle name/surname all or any part thereof, at the time of registration of marriage or even after marriage, and she shall be entitled to use her husband's name, until such time as a divorce is granted or, in case of widowhood, until she contracts a second marriage," the notification reads. Students of Ambeshi school shifted out a.description: BICHOLIM: Government officials were forced to shift 22 students of Government Primary School (GPS), Ambeshi-Pale, to a private residence nearby, after the school saw an unusual infestation of bed bugs, known as ‘bhikunn’ in Konkani. Despite numerous bugs having dropped from the rafters of the old building, officials said no students were bitten. They also said that the Goa State Infrastructure Development Corporation has been asked to repair the old school building at the earliest. Sources said a bug attack had hit the school last year too, but it continued to operate from the same premises. “The school building is over 30 years old. The structure has wooden beams supporting Manglaore tiles. As the school was closed for summer break for nearly two months, no maintenance was done during this period. With the first pre-monsoons showers, the beams got damp and bugs began breeding,” an education official said. On Monday, the bugs fell from the roof in hordes, leading to panic among students studying from Class I to IV. Additional district education inspector Shrirang Barve said the students have been shifted to the private residence of the Kanekar family that resides in the school’s vicinity, and that the existing school will be repaired as early as possible. Sources said that the officials began acting only after chief minister Pramod Sawant intervened. PTA members said they had already informed the school’s authorities about the bug infestation and had sought action in this matter, but claimed that the authorities were slow to act. Solution to Sonsoddo soon: Milind.description: PANAJI: Urban development minister Milind Naik, on Wednesday, said the government is monitoring the situation at Sonsoddo and it will come out with a solution soon. Recently, chief minister Pramod Sawant had a meeting with representatives of Fomento Green, the company managing the Sonsoddo dump. The meeting was also attended by deputy chief minister Vijai Sardesai, who is also the local MLA. “On basis of that meeting some solution is being worked out. So, there will be some solution,” Naik said. He said, solid waste management is a “serious issue” and the government is seized of it, to a query if any measures are taken to see that there is no repeat of Sonsoddo in other parts of the state. Sawant has declared plans of setting up of new waste treatment plants within a time frame. “It has to be done, else people will suffer. The MLAs should also take the issue seriously,” the urban development minister said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

In a counter complaint, Damodar Naik named two persons of assaulting him. Those arrested are Bhanudas Chavan, SagarWadyekar, Venkatesh Bhise, Damodar Naik, A Devar and Abdul Sayed. Hema Sardesai hits protest note to save.description: PANAJI: On the very day chief minister Pramod Sawant told his MLAs to take up tree plantation as part of Vanamohotsav, a group of citizens led by singer Hema Sardesai held a protest against the cutting of iconic trees to make way for renovation work of the St Inez crematorium. The protests began after a couple of the age-old trees were felled, and activists tried to save the rest. Alongside Sardesai were historian Prajal Sakhardande, social activist Patricia Pinto, and others. After the protests, the citizens made their way to the Panaji police station to file a complaint. The protestors said that when the reconstruction of the crematorium was planned, authorities had promised that the trees would not be touched. Thus, Sardesai said that they were “shocked” to learn on Monday morning that the trees were being felled. She added that the felling was halted after calls were made to several ministers. The protestors said that officials from the Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) washed their hands off the tree-cutting, and blamed the Goa State Urban Development Agency (GSUDA). They also wanted to know why CCP shrugged off all responsibility and refused to intervene. Meanwhile, Sakhardande said that they would not allow any more trees to be cut at the site. Pinto said that development means more than concretisation, and that preserving trees was an essential part of keeping the city developed. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BJP List 2019 Karnataka.description: BENGALURU: The BJP on Thursday released its first list of 21 candidates from Karnataka, but it does not include the names of sitting MP Karadi Sanganna (Koppal) or late Union minister HN Ananth Kumar’s wife Tejaswini, who is widely tipped to be the candidate from Bengaluru South. The list names the 14 other sitting MPs, including Shobha Karandlaje (Udupi-Chikkamagalur) and Suresh Angadi (Belagavi) despite stiff opposition within the party and anti-incumbency against the two. Party leaders said they are baffled by the exclusion of Tejaswini’s name and are unaware of the reasons for her candidature being withheld. “We inaugurated her personal office on Thursday and were sure of her name being announced,” one leader said. Rumours — from “technical” errors to the possibility that her name would lead to comments on “dynasty politics” — are doing the rounds. Sanganna’s candidature was withheld as the BJP is waiting for the JD(S)-Congress coalition to name its candidate. With the possibility of former chief minister Siddaramaiah contesting, the BJP will require a stronger candidate. The party also decided not to announce its candidate for Mandya, but two Congress rebels — A Manju from Hassan and Umesh Jadhav from Kalaburagi — have been given tickets. BSY has his wayThe first list confirms that the BJP central leadership continues to repose faith in state party president and Lingayat strongman BS Yeddyurappa. The list features names of his son BY Raghavendra and several confidants. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .
